tossups.question: In addiction module systems, cells lacking specific examples of these structures tend to die due to a lack of antitoxin production. Iterons maintain the copy number of these structures, which may be stringent or relaxed depending on that copy number. One of these structures that is commonly used as a cloning vector contains a single ori site and is named pBR322. Esther Lederberg discovered the first of these entities called the (*) fertility factor, which enables horizontal gene transfer via conjugation. Antibiotic resistance genes are typically found on these mobile genetic elements. These structures are the primary source of extrachromosomal genetic material in bacteria. For 10 points, name these circular bits of DNA.
tossups.answer: plasmids

tossups.question: In one film, this actress wore a white gown with black embroidered flowers and “yards of skirt.” In that film, she played a chauffeur’s daughter who is pursued by both William Holden and Humphrey Bogart. In another film, this woman’s guards find her at a dance on a barge, causing a brawl in which she hits one of them over the head with a guitar. In that film, she played a princess who rides through the title city on a (*) vespa with Gregory Peck. In a third film, this actress sits on a fire escape, plays a guitar, and sings “Moon River.” That film opens with her eating a pastry beside the title store while wearing a “little black dress.” For 10 points, name this star of Sabrina, Roman Holiday, and Breakfast at Tiffany’s.
tossups.answer: Audrey Hepburn [or Audrey Kathleen Ruston; prompt on Hepburn]

tossups.question: This philosopher’s attempt to start a university career failed when he intentionally scheduled his lectures at the same time as those of a much more popular rival. An essay about this philosopher declares, “There is in the world one road whereon none may go, except thou”; that Friedrich Nietzsche essay considers this philosopher “as Educator.” This philosopher’s writings on aesthetics, in which he praises (*) music as the only art that is not a “copy of the Ideas,” inspired artists like Richard Wagner. Influenced by the Upanishads, this philosopher laid out a Kantian worldview in which the underlying “Thing-In-Itself” is blind, self-devouring impulse. For 10 points, name this 19th-century German idealist, the pessimistic author of The World as Will and Representation.
tossups.answer: Arthur Schopenhauer

tossups.question: The monstrous statues found in a house built by this man are the origin of the word “grotesque.” According to Suetonius, that house built by this man had pipes that could be opened to dispense flowers and perfume. A giant statue of this emperor, later re-dedicated to Sol, likely provided the nickname for Vespasian’s Colosseum. After the destruction of the Transitoria on the Esquiline Hill, this man built the (*) Domus Aurea. This emperor allegedly employed a sabotaged boat in a plot to drown his own mother and was himself the target of the Pisonian conspiracy. This man’s death sparked the Year of the Four Emperors. For 10 points, name this successor to Claudius who reigned during the Great Fire of Rome.
tossups.answer: Nero [or Nero Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus; or Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus]

tossups.question: This modern-day country was the discovery site of an ancient cross relief with a floret design, which might have been cut by the ancient Christians of “Taprobane.” Many shrines in this country have “moonstones” with concentric bands of carvings placed at the foot of their steps. The Portuguese may have destroyed one of the sacred relics of this country, a sacred tooth enshrined at (*) Kandy (“candy”). This country was the site of the Fourth Buddhist Council that committed the Pali Canon into writing. In Easter 2019, an Islamist group in this country launched a bombing attack on three churches in Colombo in this country. This country’s Kataragama temple is devoted to Lord Murugan, who is frequently worshiped by Tamils. For 10 points, name this country home to many Sinhalese Buddhists.
tossups.answer: Sri Lanka [or Ceylon]

tossups.question: Robert Clive was the original owner of a Claude Joseph Vernet painting of one of these events that was paired with Landscape at Sunset. A painting of one of these events was commissioned as a companion piece to Southern Nature in her Abundant and Majestic Splendor. The word “Griper” can be seen in a Caspar David Friedrich painting of the aftermath of one of these events in the Arctic. Preparatory sketches for a work featuring (*) survivors of one of these events were made at a morgue. That work depicts an African man waving a banner at the Argus from atop a pyramid of bodies. For 10 points, Théodore Géricault painted people stranded in the aftermath of what type of event in The Raft of the Medusa?
tossups.answer: shipwreck [accept descriptive answers describing a ship having an accident or disaster or similar; prompt on disaster at sea or equivalents that do not explicitly mention ships; prompt on storm at sea or similar; do not accept or prompt on answers involving “mutinies”]

tossups.question: In Stephen Mitchell’s translation, this poet described a “ritual dance around a circle / in which a mighty will stands paralyzed.” In another of his poems, an internal “brilliance” allows a “smile” to run down to “that dark center where procreation flared.” This author wrote of an animal who “paces in cramped circles” behind what seems to be “a thousand bars” in one of his “thing poems,” which were inspired in part by his friendship with Auguste (*) Rodin. In the first poem in part two of his New Poems, this German-language poet of “The Panther” stated, “We cannot know his legendary head” when analyzing a sculpture of a Greek god’s trunk. For 10 points, name this poet who wrote “you must change your life” in “Archaic Torso of Apollo” and penned The Duino Elegies.
tossups.answer: Rainer Maria Rilke

tossups.question: A “multiple-effect” system for performing this process chains devices at successively lower pressures and was invented by Norbert Rillieux (“nor-BAIR ree-YUH”). When outlet pressure is less than inlet pressure, this process can occur via an adiabatic flash. Traps are inserted to avoid contamination when this process occurs violently. This process is performed in round-bottom flasks with bumping chips. This task is often performed by spinning flasks through a (*) heat bath under vacuum conditions using a “rotary” device. The latent heat required for this process is strictly greater than the enthalpy of fusion. Distillation separates substances based on how much they undergo this process. For 10 points, name this phase change from liquid to gas.
tossups.answer: evaporation [or evaporating; accept vaporization, vaporizing, or enthalpy of vaporization; accept boiling; accept rotary evaporation; prompt on using a rotovap; prompt on distillation before mentioned; prompt on solvent removal or sample concentration by asking “what process is being used for that?”]

tossups.question: In this novel, after a girl dies, her mother sorrowfully “trumpets for the sky itself to hear” the words “And she was loved!” A tune about a “Sugarman” appears throughout this novel, whose protagonist hears the phrase “Your day has come” while being choked by a friend who joins the radical Seven Days organization. In this novel, a woman without a navel owns a “bag of gold” that is actually full of (*) human bones. Some children in this novel are named by randomly sticking a pin in a Bible. This novel opens with Robert Smith jumping off the roof of Mercy Hospital. At its end, Guitar shoots Pilate, and the protagonist finally learns how to “fly.” For 10 points, Milkman Dead is the protagonist of what Toni Morrison novel named for a Biblical book?
tossups.answer: Song of Solomon

tossups.question: In 1977, the B’nai B’rith headquarters in this city was taken hostage by Hamaas Abdul Khaalis to protest the film Messenger of God. In 2020, a noise complaint from T-Mobile led this city to designate go-go as its official music. Walter Fauntroy called for this city to waive its building height limits to help its Black neighborhoods recover from the worst MLK riots in the US. A former SNCC chair was re-elected to a fourth mayoral term in this city despite being (*) arrested on crack cocaine charges in 1990. Marion Barry administered this city following Congress’s 1973 Home Rule Act. The 23rd Amendment granted citizens of this city the right to vote for president. For 10 points, Pierre Charles L’Enfant (“lawn-FAWN”) helped design what US capital?
tossups.answer: Washington, D.C. [or District of Columbia; or D.C.]

tossups.question: A novel by this author begins by describing how an executioner feels a “sharp pang of appetite” after an execution that “reminds him that it is time for a second breakfast.” Beyond Black was the first of four novels by this author that were shortlisted for the Women’s Prize for Fiction. She wrote about a man who makes angel wings out of peacock feathers for his daughter Grace. A novel by this author opens with the command “So now get up,” which is spoken by the protagonist’s abusive father Walter. This author included fictional versions of (*) Lord Chancellor Stephen Gardiner and Jane Seymour in a trilogy of novels that recently concluded with The Mirror and the Light. For 10 points, name this author who wrote about Thomas Cromwell in Wolf Hall.
tossups.answer: Hilary Mantel [or Hilary Mary Mantel]

tossups.question: Modern instruments for observing these objects exploit the high spectral resolution of echelle (“ay-SHELL”) gratings to study their characteristic Gaussian cross-correlation lineshape. Viscous gas present during the formation of these objects decreases the lifetime of dust at the one-meter hurdle. Queloz and Mayor split half the 2019 Nobel Prize in Physics for using Doppler shifts to study these objects. The known number of these objects increased (*) sharply in 2014 and 2016 as data was released from the Kepler telescope, which looked for the dips in luminosity associated with transits. Methods for detecting these objects are biased towards large examples found inside the Goldilocks zone. For 10 points, name these objects that are often compared to Earth.
tossups.answer: extrasolar planets [or exoplanets; accept gas giants, hot Jupiters, or mega-Earths; prompt on planetesimals before “known number” is read]

tossups.question: An exceptionally large one of these things named for Lindsey Creek was destroyed in 1905. The “Jackson” one of these things in Athens, Georgia, unusually has legal ownership over its land. Julius Sterling Morton helped popularize a Nebraska holiday centered on these things that was later endorsed by Theodore Roosevelt. Environmentalists prevented Disney from building a ski lodge in a park named for a type of these things that also contains the (*) tallest peak in the contiguous US, Mount Whitney. A road passes through the “Chandelier” one of these things, which is slightly smaller in size than one named for General William Tecumseh Sherman. For 10 points, name these plants, giant examples of which are found in California’s Sequoia National Park.
tossups.answer: trees [accept more specific types of trees such as oak tree or redwood tree; accept giant sequoia tree or Sequoia National Park until read; prompt on plants] (The holiday is Arbor Day.)

tossups.question: An instance of this specific action is blamed on atasthalia, or “recklessness,” in an epic proem about a character described by the epithet polytropos. Heracles foiled an attempt to perform this action by choking a fire-breathing son of Vulcan so hard that his eyes bulged out; that instance of this action was carried out by Cacus. Sisyphus writes the letters “SS” several times in an attempt to prevent (*) Autolycus from completing this task. It does not involve killing, but Eurylochus dooms all of Odysseus’s men when he provokes Helios by performing this action. For his tenth labor, Heracles perpetrated this crime against a three-chested giant. For 10 points, name this specific action that Heracles performed on livestock owned by Geryon.
tossups.answer: cattle theft [or stealing cows; accept equivalents for stealing and for cows; accept eating cattle before “Vulcan” is read; prompt on theft or stealing by asking “what was stolen?”]

tossups.question: This country was the only one to officially protest the Anschluss to the League of Nations even though it was home to its own Gold Shirts fascist movement. An international boycott of this country began in 1938 after its president invoked Article 27 of its Constitution of 1917, nationalizing a prominent industry. A long-ruling political party in this country had a system called the dedazo, where the president chose his successor, and emerged from a period called the (*) Maximato. An exile living in this country survived an assassination attempt by a muralist before being killed by an NKVD agent with an ice axe. For 10 points, Lazaro Cardenas’s PRI party long controlled what Latin American country where Leon Trotsky was assassinated?
tossups.answer: Mexico [or United Mexican States; or Estados Unidos Mexicanos]

tossups.question: Large values of this quantity cause Fowler–Nordheim tunneling. This quantity reaches a peak value inside the depletion region of an unbiased p–n junction. Changing this value to affect the conductivity of a metal is the operating principle behind FETs (“fets”). Because this quantity is uniform inside of a parallel plate capacitor, the voltage can be calculated as this quantity times the (*) separation distance. Van de Graaf generators exploit the fact that this quantity is higher for conductors with a higher curvature. The charge density divided by the permittivity of free space is equal to this quantity’s divergence according to Gauss’s law. For 10 points, name this vector field that measures the intensity of the Coulomb force.
tossups.answer: electric field

tossups.question: In the opening of Joseph Haydn’s oratorio The Creation, the orchestra plays a massive fortissimo chord in this key to accompany the words “And There Was Light.” The majority of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart’s masses are in this key, which is also the key of Haydn’s Mass in Time of War. The sixth and ninth symphonies of Franz Schubert are nicknamed the (*) “Little” and “Great” symphonies in this key. Mozart composed his sixteenth piano sonata, which is often nicknamed “Simple,” in this key, which was also used for his Jupiter Symphony. Bach used this key for the first prelude and fugue in Book One of The Well-Tempered Clavier. Its relative minor is A minor, and its third and fifth scale degrees are E and G. For 10 points, name this key that has no sharps or flats.
tossups.answer: C major

tossups.question: A revolt against this colonial power was started after two elders symbolically uprooted three cotton plants; that revolt against this European country was named for the “magic water” or “maji” in Kinjikitile’s (“kin-jee-kih-TEE-lay’s”) war medicine. Huge numbers of people in a colony controlled by this country died when they fled into the Omaheke Desert and were cut off from water. In 1890, the UK ceded Katima Mulilo and other parts of the (*) Caprivi Strip to this country. This country’s forces carried out the Herero Genocide. An 1884 meeting held in this country formalized Belgian king Leopold II’s control over the Congo Free State. For 10 points, name this country where European powers gathered to carve up Africa at the Berlin Conference.
tossups.answer: Germany [or Federal Republic of Germany; or Deutschland; or German Empire; or Imperial State of Germany; or Second Reich; anti-prompt on Prussia]

tossups.question: A poem about this activity begins by invoking the “Muses of Pieria” (“py-AIR-ee-uh”) and explaining the two different forms of Strife. Geoponici (“gay-oh-po-nee-kee”) refer to works about this activity, including the writings of Columella and a treatise by Cato the Elder. A poem about this activity ends with an epyllion about Aristaeus that includes an early version of the Orpheus and Eurydice myth. A poetic treatise instructing the author’s brother Perses in this activity explains the Five (*) Ages of Man and the story of Pandora’s box. The author of the Eclogues wrote a Latin poem about this activity that discusses the behavior of bees in its fourth and final book. For 10 points, Hesiod’s Works and Days and Virgil’s Georgics center on what rustic activity, the main domain of Demeter?
tossups.answer: farming [or agriculture; or harvesting; accept animal husbandry; accept answers like growing crops]

tossups.question: This scholar controversially built on Geoffrey Gorer’s “swaddle thesis” about Russian power for the RAND-published Soviet Attitudes Toward Authority. An earlier work by this scholar examined the importance of “Sir Ghosts” to one society. This author described how children are given prominence over matai in informal dance ceremonies in a book that may have become a best-seller due to the topless girl on its dust jacket. In that book, this anthropologist described a day opening with (*) lovers returning from “trysts beneath the palm trees or in the shadow of beached canoes” on the island of Tau, a society that supposedly did not cherish virginity. For 10 points, name this woman who wrote Coming of Age in Samoa.
tossups.answer: Margaret Mead

tossups.question: One of these title things appears “in the Garden Room” in a chapter by Elizabeth Gaskell for a collaborative story printed in the 1859 Christmas edition of All the Year Round. Shouts of “Below there!” cause a railroad worker to notice one of these things in the story “The Signal-Man.” In an 1843 novella, one of these figures has the children Ignorance and Want clinging to his green robes. Another of these figures has a (*) candle flame for a head and takes a man to Mr. Fezziwig’s ball. The miserly protagonist of a novella encounters a chained one of these figures who resembles his partner Jacob Marley. For 10 points, Scrooge is visited by what kind of figures representing Christmas Past, Present, and Future?
tossups.answer: ghosts [or spirits; or phantoms; or apparitions; or wraiths; or spectres; accept “The Ghost in the Garden Room”; accept Ghosts of Christmas or Spirits of Christmas] (The first story is “The Haunted House.”)

bonuses.leadin: In the 1980s, this then-40-year-old book became a must-read in Hollywood after screenwriter Christopher Vogler distributed a summary of it to his coworkers. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Hero with a Thousand Faces
parts: Identify this Joseph Campbell book about the “monomyth.” It argued that there were universal rules for storytelling.
The Hero with a Thousand Faces examines the story of this Titan from Greek mythology, who has his liver repeatedly ripped out for stealing fire.

In the 1870s, this anthropologist noted many similarities in hero myths across the world. In his best-known book, he used the term “animism” to describe primitive religious practices, which persisted into later times as “survivals.”

bonuses.leadin: In a letter to Javier Marías, this author said he wouldn’t dare “add a single line” to Sir Thomas Browne’s “matchless prose.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Jorge Luis Borges (The story is “Tlön, Uqbar, Orbis Tertius.”)
Spanish Golden Age [or Siglo de Oro]
bestiary [accept answers indicating books about mythical creatures or animals; accept Book of Imaginary Beings]
parts: Name this author who translated the 5th chapter of Browne’s Urn Burial with Adolfo Bioy Casares (“b’YOY ka-SAH-race”). He references “an uncertain Quevedian translation” of the book at the end of a story about the world of Tlön.
Browne lived in the 1600s, so Borges translated his work into the Baroque language of this “age” of Spanish literature during which Lope de Vega wrote.
Browne’s Pseudodoxia Epidemica, which refutes assorted “vulgar errors,” likely inspired a book by Borges in this genre whose contents are “imaginary.” Description acceptable.

bonuses.leadin: Girolamo Frescobaldi included eleven of these pieces in his influential second book of them. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: toccata [prompt on toccata and fugue, asking “which one?”; do not accept or prompt on “fugue”]
set of variations [or theme and variations; or variation set; accept Goldberg Variations]
parts: Name this Baroque genre. A piece in D minor that uses this genre in its first section and another genre in its second section begins with a mordant on A and opens the original Fantasia film.
Frescobaldi wrote the first work of this type on an original theme. A composition of this type by J. S. Bach, allegedly written to help a count sleep, was named for Johann Gottlieb Goldberg.
Frescobaldi’s Second Book of Toccatas contains the first examples of this genre and the closely related passacaglia. Bach’s second violin partita closes with a famous piece of this type.

bonuses.leadin: T. H. Huxley claimed that this theory was equivalent to explaining that water acts the way it does because of its “aquosity.” For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this dismissed theory which states that there is a “force” present in living matter but not in dead matter.

Though not his original intent, Fredrich Wöhler (“VER-ler”) undermined vitalism by synthesizing this nitrogenous compound in 1828, writing to Berzelius that he could make it “without the use of kidneys of any animal.”
Wöhler’s synthesis of urea is considered a foundational step in this field, the chemistry of carbon-containing compounds.

bonuses.leadin: In one experiment, subjects who could see these objects lasted four minutes less than subjects who knew they were there but couldn’t see them. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: marshmallows [accept the marshmallow experiment; accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, Stanford marshmallow experiment]
replication crisis [or reproducibility crisis; or replicability crisis; accept anything involving not being able to reproduce study results]
parts: Identify these objects that name an experiment first conducted on children by Walter Mischel.
The marshmallow experiment was originally conducted at this university, where Philip Zimbardo conducted a notorious prison experiment.

The marshmallow experiment has been challenged as part of this broader problem in the social sciences that arguably began with reactions to Daryl Bem’s 2010 paper “Feeling the Future.” Description acceptable.

bonuses.leadin: Before some 11,000 of these devices were thrown into the Hudson River, New York City cops removed their wooden legs to refashion into billy clubs. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: pinball machines [prompt on coin-op or coin-operated machines or arcade machines]
Fiorello Henry La Guardia [or Fiorello Enrico La Guardia]
Humpty Dumpty [prompt on partial answer] (The novel is All the King’s Men.)
parts: Identify these amusement devices long banned due to their associations with gambling.
This mayor of New York City was photographed taking a sledgehammer to a pinball machine. He now lends his name to one of New York’s two airports.

The first pinball game to include flippers was a game titled for this character. A line from a nursery rhyme about this character titles a 1946 novel in which narrator Jack Burden eventually learns that his father was Judge Irwin.

bonuses.leadin: The Everett interpretation, or the many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics, denies the possibility of this occurrence. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Eugene Paul Wigner [or Wigner Jenő Pál]
parts: Name this occurrence, the reduction of a wavefunction to a single eigenstate.
Wavefunctions collapse upon undergoing any sort of interaction with the external world, which is given this name. The uncertainty principle provides limits on this activity.

This Hungarian-American physicist suggested a thought experiment in which an observer performing a quantum measurement is further observed by another observer, which many interpretations suggest would give contradictory results. His namesake “friend” experiment can thus be considered an extension of Schrödinger’s cat.

bonuses.leadin: In the 16th century, woadmen’s guilds persuaded several European governments to ban the import of this “devil’s dye” since it was putting them out of work. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Royal Navy [or British Navy; or RN; or English Navy; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Identify this dye. It was the most widely used dye in European textile manufacturing in the 18th century.
By the 18th century, the standard uniform for officers in this force was dyed with blue indigo. This force prevented a French invasion by winning the Battle of Trafalgar.
Eliza Lucas Pinckney encouraged slave plantations in this modern-day US state to grow indigo. The Battle of Camden Court House was fought in this state in 1780.

bonuses.leadin: In 1943, this man met with Colonel John Lansdale to discuss an earlier meeting that he had with Haakon Chevalier. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Manhattan Project [or Development of Substitute Materials]
parts: Name this man whose relationship with Jean Tatlock, a writer for the Western Worker, would be addressed during a 1954 security hearing headed by Gordon Gray.
In 1954, this man helped revoke Oppenheimer’s security clearance. As head of an organization, this man ran the COINTELPRO program.
Despite his perceived communist associations, Leslie Groves still managed to convince the government to hire Oppenheimer as the chief scientist on this project to develop the atomic bomb.

bonuses.leadin: In a short story, Pahom consoles himself by thinking, “An hour to suffer, a lifetime to live,” as he walks for miles on the steppe as part of a deal to get this resource from a Bashkir tribe. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: land [accept farmland; accept real estate; accept “How Much Land Does a Man Need?”]
parts: Name this resource that Pahom boasts would let him “not fear the Devil himself,” causing the Devil to tempt him with it.
“How Much Land Does a Man Need?” was written by this Russian author, who remarked, “Happy families are all alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way” in Anna Karenina.
Kozeltsóf is ashamed to admit to his older brother that he lost his money playing Préférence in one of three war “sketches” by Tolstoy set in this city.

bonuses.leadin: The advent of dot-matrix and laser printer technologies spurred the development of page description languages, or PDLs, to encode the information needed to print text. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: reverse Polish notation [or postfix notation; do not accept or prompt on “Polish notation”]
parts: This company created the early PDL PostScript, which uses only lines and Bézier (“BEH-zee-ay”) curves. ISO has standardized this company’s portable document format.
This last-in, first-out data structure is used by PostScript to organize its data. The font is pushed into this structure first, then other operations are popped off the top when the page is shown.
Stacks were used to store values in old calculators that operated using this mathematical notation. In this notation, arguments and parameters are placed before operators.

bonuses.leadin: This artist attempted to sell silver spheres to people as part of her performance art piece Narcissus Garden. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: department stores [accept luxury department stores; prompt on retailers or stores; do not accept “malls”]
parts: Name this Japanese artist who is most famous for her polka-dot pumpkins and for her Infinity Room installations.

Yayoi Kusama collaborated with this gay American fashion designer on a collection for Louis Vuitton. This man introduced Louis Vuitton’s first ready-to-wear line while serving as their creative director from 1997 to 2014.
In the 1960s, Kusama designed pieces for Bloomingdale’s, one of these businesses. Lord & Taylor was another of these businesses named for their numerous specialty sections.

bonuses.leadin: The English agricultural season traditionally began on Plough Monday, the first Monday after this other holiday. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Epiphany [or Theophany; or Three Kings’ Day; accept Little Christmas; do not accept or prompt on “Christmas”]
Annunciation to the Blessed Virgin Mary [or Annunciation of Our Lady; or Annunciation of the Lord]
John the Baptist [or John the Forerunner; or John the Baptizer; prompt on John]
parts: Name this holiday for which the hymn “As with Gladness Men of Old” was originally composed. The night before this holiday is known as Twelfth Night.
Until 1752, the first day of each year in England was Lady Day, the holiday celebrating this event in which Mary was told by Gabriel that she would give birth to Jesus.
In England, the pagan holiday of Midsummer was replaced with a feast honoring this saint. Another feast commemorating this man’s death is sometimes called the Decollation.

bonuses.leadin: This character impresses her chemistry professor by pretending to take notes on formulas, though she is really writing poetry instead. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this clinically depressed character who undergoes electroconvulsive therapy. She works as an intern under Jay Cee for Ladies’ Day magazine.
Esther is the protagonist of this only novel written by Sylvia Plath, published just one month before Plath took her own life.

In the novel, Esther visits her ex-boyfriend Buddy, who has this last name, at a sanitorium in the Adirondacks. This is also the last name of George, a reporter for the Eagle in Sherwood Anderson’s Winesburg, Ohio.

bonuses.leadin: The 1657 Great Fire of Meireki (“MAY-reh-kee”) may have begun when a priest burned a cursed one of these items. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: shoes [or clogs; or flip-flops; or footwear; or sandals; or anything equivalent to shoes]
parts: Identify these garments usually made from one long 14-inch-wide bolt of silk. Obi are subtypes of these garments.
So-called propaganda kimonos increased in popularity following the Japanese invasion of this part of Northern China in 1931 and the establishment of the State of Manchukuo.
Geta, traditional Japanese examples of these items of clothing, came in many varieties, including the okobo used by geishas who were still in training.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about the growing drug problem in Africa.
answers_sanitized: khat [or qat; or gat; or jaad; or chat]
parts: Africa, like Europe, gets most of its heroin from the poppy fields of this country, where opium production has long funded the Taliban.

Scholar Joseph Hanlon has estimated that heroin is this country’s second-biggest export. This Southeast African country’s president Filipe Nyusi visited the hideout of RENAMO leader Afonso Dhlakama to negotiate a power-sharing agreement.
Suhura Ismail built an international business selling this stimulant in Ethiopia. The US bans this appetite suppressant, but it’s widely chewed like gum in Yemen.

bonuses.leadin: Hamilton Fish introduced a bill to create one of these types of memorials in the United States. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: tomb of the unknown soldier [or unknown warrior; prompt on war memorial or World War I memorial]
parts: Identify this type of memorial. In 1921, Sergeant Edward Younger randomly selected the body to use for an American memorial of this type.
Sergeant Younger was in this country when he chose the body of the unknown soldier. This country’s own Tomb of the Unknown Soldier is placed under the Arc de Triomphe.

Brazil’s memorial honors members of the Brazilian Expeditionary Force killed trying to capture this Axis defensive position. Operation Olive partially broke through this line defended by Albert Kesselring in Italy’s Apennine (“APP-uh-nine”) Mountains.

bonuses.leadin: This phenomenon donates energy in a technique called BRET. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: bioluminescence [accept biofluorescence; accept chemiluminescence; accept green fluorescent protein; prompt on light emission]
parts: Name this phenomenon exhibited by firefly luciferins, aequorin, and a “green” protein found in jellyfish.

The bioluminescence seen in the Bobtail squid is controlled by bacteria in the squid’s light organ. The bacteria only exhibit luminescence when this quantity is high in a phenomenon called quorum sensing.

The luciferin–luciferase system in A. fischeri is coded for by one of these sets of linked genes typically composed of a promoter, a namesake segment that can be bound by a repressor, and structural genes. One of them in E. coli is required for the metabolism of lactose.

bonuses.leadin: In an adaptation of this play by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, actors are assigned roles at random via an onstage lottery. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Jesus Christ [or Jesus Christ; accept answers like the baby Jesus or the Christ child]
parts: Name this play whose title character uses the “scourge of penance” on himself in front of Confession to repent for his sins.
Everyman is part of this genre of medieval theatre that typically includes allegorical characters like Confession and Good Deeds. This genre is the more secular descendant of the mystery play.

The mystery play The Second Shepherds’ Play sees shepherds give cherries, a bird, and a ball to this religious figure as an infant. Another medieval genre, the Passion Play, depicts this man’s suffering and death.

bonuses.leadin: A national tour of these paintings raised 133 million dollars for war bonds. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Four Freedoms [or Four Freedoms series]
Madison Square Garden [or Madison Square Garden Center; or the Garden; or MSG; accept answers like the old Madison Square Garden]
parts: Name this series of paintings, one of which is set at a town meeting in New England. Another of these paintings depicts an elderly woman in an apron setting a turkey down on a table.
The Four Freedoms series was painted by this artist, best known for his cover illustrations for The Saturday Evening Post.

Walter Russell’s Four Freedoms Monument was dedicated at this New York City landmark in 1943. Augustus Saint-Gaudens’s controversial nude sculpture of Diana shooting an arrow was commissioned for this building, which it topped until 1925.

bonuses.leadin: When shown visions of locusts and fire, this prophet twice implores, “O Lord God, please forgive! How can Jacob stand? He is so small!”, causing God to relent. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: shepherd [or herdsman or herder or pastoralist; or ra‘ah or ro‘eh or boqer]
parts: Name this minor prophet whose declaration “Let justice roll down like waters, and righteousness like an ever-flowing stream” was quoted by Martin Luther King.
The Book of Amos introduces Amos as someone with this vocation. In Psalm 23, God is likened to someone with this vocation who “makes me lie down in green pastures.”
Amos’s prophecy begins by declaring that the Lord “roars” from this specific place. In Psalm 137, Israelites sit down and weep “by the waters of Babylon” when they remember this specific place.
